questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Table 1 lists various components of the human immune system and some of their actions. An antigen is a foreign substance that elicits an immune response. An antibody is a molecule that binds specific antigens.

Figures 1 and 2 show the time periods during which cell and/or antibody concentrations are typically above normal during the 28 days after first exposure to an antigen.

Figure 3 shows the stages of infection in humans exposed to the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the virus that causes AIDS.



Table 1 and Figure 3 adapted from Neil A. Campbell, Biology, 3rd ed.
©1993 by the Benjamin/Cummings Publishing Company, Inc.





Figure 1 and 2 adapted from Peter H. Raven and George B. Johnson,
Understanding Biology. ©1988 by Times Mirror/Mosby College Publishing.
questions.question: 1. According to Figure 3, approximately how many years after a patient's first exposure to HIV will the patient's helper T cell concentration fall below 40 cells/cm³？

questions.question: 2. Blood banks screen donations for the presence of viruses by measuring the concentration of IgG antibodies. Based on Figure 2, how many days after the first exposure to a virus would the concentration of IgG antibodies be highest in the blood?

questions.question: 3. According to Figure 2, which of the following correctly lists the order, from first to last, in which the 3 types of T cells first appear at above-normal concentrations after first exposure to the antigen?

choices.A: Cytotoxic T cells, helper T cells, suppressor T cells
choices.B: Cytotoxic T cells, suppressor T cells, helper T cells
choices.C: Helper T cells, cytotoxic T cells, suppressor T cells
choices.D: Helper T cells, suppressor T cells, cytotoxic T cells

questions.question: 5. According to Figure 3, after first exposure to HIV, the HIV concentration decreases by the greatest amount during which of the following time periods?

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
As earthworms move through the soil, they leave behind open burrows. These burrows may enhance the growth of plant roots by providing paths that the roots can easily follow as they grow.

A study was done to see if more plant roots and/or deeper plant roots are produced in soil containing 1 of 2 types of earthworms compared to soil without earthworms. Type A earthworms create horizontal burrows down to a maximum depth of 15 cm that collapse within minutes. The burrows of Type A earthworms typically do not reach the surface. Type B earthworms create vertical burrows from the surface down to a maximum depth of 30 cm that remain open for several days.

Nine boxes without bottoms and having sides 0.5 m high were prepared, and each was placed in a hole in the ground at an outdoor site so that the tops of the boxes were even with the ground surface. Each box was then filled with identical fertilized soil. Forty Type A earthworms were added to each of 3 boxes, and 40 Type B earthworms were added to each of 3 other boxes. The remaining 3 boxes contained no earthworms. Five days after the earthworms were added, seeds of barley, wheat, or oats were planted in the boxes.

Equal numbers of barley seeds were planted in 1 box containing Type A earthworms, 1 box containing Type B earthworms, and 1 box containing no earthworms. The same procedure was followed for wheat and oat seeds. All 9 boxes received equal amounts of sunlight and water. After 12 weeks, the dry mass of the roots in each box was measured for each 5 cm depth of soil in which roots were present (see Figure 1).






Figure 1 adapted from S. D. Logsdon and D. R. Linden, "Interactions of Earthworms with Soil Conditions Influencing Plant Growth." ©1992 by Williams and Wilkins.
questions.question: 6. Regarding the root depth of barley, wheat, and oats, the results of the study indicate that, in general, for soil without earthworms, the maximum depth that is reached by:

choices.A: barley roots is less than the maximum depth reached by wheat roots.
choices.B: barley roots is the same as the maximum depth reached by wheat roots.
choices.C: wheat roots is less than the maximum depth reached by oat roots.
choices.D: wheat roots is the same as the maximum depth reached by oat roots.

questions.question: 9.  Earthworms were allowed to live in the boxes for 5 days before seeds were planted to allow time for the earthworms to:

choices.A: remove most nutrients from the fertilized soil.
choices.B: add nutrients to the unfertilized soil.
choices.C: close any existing openings in the soil.
choices.D: create numerous openings in the soil.

questions.question: 10. It has been hypothesized that increased root mass is associated with increased plant matter above ground. Which of the following additional data should have been gathered to best test this hypothesis?

choices.A: The total mass of the soil clinging to the roots of the plants in each box
choices.B: The total dry mass of the plant stems and leaves in each box
choices.C: The average width of plant leaves in each box
choices.D: The total number of earthworms in each box

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article: A tropical depression is a weak storm that forms over warm, tropical ocean waters. A tropical depression that strengthens may become a tropical storm, which may, in turn, strengthen further and become a hurricane. Hurricanes produce heavy rain, high winds, and storm surges (a flood of ocean water). Table 1 shows the sustained wind speeds of the 3 types of storms. Table 2 shows how a hurricane's central air pressure, wind speed, and storm surge height correspond to hurricane Intensity ratings 1-5. Figure 1 shows central air pressure and wind speed data from 3 storms over 11 days gathered by aircraft that flew rough the storms.
questions.question: 12. Which of the following figures best represents the wind speeds at the start of Day 7 for Storms 1-3 in Figure 1?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
When 2 aqueous (water-based) solutions are mixed together, a chemical reaction between the substances dissolved in the solutions may take place. Evidence of a chemical reaction includes one or more of the following:
formation of a precipitate (ppt, a solid)
release of heat to the solution (solution gets hotter)
absorption of heat from the solution (solution gets colder)
release of a gas (indicated by the formation of bubbles or by an odor)

The table below shows what was observed when various aqueous solutions were mixed.



Table adapted from J. Dudley et al., Health Chemistry—Teacher's Annotated Edition. ©1987 by D. C. Health and Company.
questions.question: 17. HCl is a strong acid when dissolved in water. When a strong acid is mixed with a strong base, heat is released. Which substance listed in the table is most likely a strong base?

questions.question: 21. An aqueous CoSO4 solution was mixed with 1 of the other solutions listed in the table and a red solid formed. A chemist claimed that the other solution must have contained K2CO3. Based on the table, is his claim valid?

choices.A: NO; the other solution could have contained NaOH instead of K2CO3.
choices.B: NO; when CoSO4 is mixed with K2CO3, a white precipitate forms.
choices.C: Yes; when CoSO4 is mixed with K2CO3, a red precipitate forms.
choices.D: Yes; no other solution form a red precipitate when mixed with CoSO4.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
When a sperm fertilizes a sea urchin egg, the egg's cortical granules (spherical structure, each bound by a membrane) fuse with the egg's plasma membrane. The contents of the granules, which include Ca2+ (unbound calcium ions), are released outward into the area between the plasma membrane and the vitelline layer (the egg's outer layer) in a process called the cortical reaction. The vitelline layer then expands to form the fertilization membrane. The fertilization membrane prevents other sperm from fusing with the egg (see figure 1).


Two experiments were done to study the hypothesis that the sperm causes the egg to release Ca2+ into the cytoplasm, which then triggers the cortical reaction.

Experiment 1
Three suspensions of unfertilized sea urchin eggs in seawater containing no Ca2+ were prepared. Aequorin, a substance that luminesces (shines) in the presence of Ca2+, was injected into the eggs' cytoplasm. Sea urchin sperm or an ionophore (a substance that can enter an egg and transport Ca2+ across membranes) was then added to 2 of the suspensions. Eggs were examined for luminescence in the cytoplasm and for the presence of a fertilization membrane (see Table 1).

Experiment 2
Experiment 1 was repeated except that both aequorin and a substance called EDTA (which binds with Ca2+, keeping it from reacting with other substances) were injected (see Table 1).
questions.question: 22. Suppose that a suspension was prepared as in Experiment 1; that aequorin was injected into the eggs; and that both sperm and the ionophore were then added to the suspension. Based on the results of Experiment 1, which of the following would most likely occur?

choices.A: Luminescence in the cytoplasm: no;Formation of fertilization membrane: yes.
choices.B: Luminescence in the cytoplasm: yes;   Formation of fertilization membrane: no.
choices.C: Luminescence in the cytoplasm: yes;   Formation of fertilization membrane: yes.
choices.D: Luminescence in the cytoplasm: no;   Formation of fertilization membrane: no.

questions.question: 23. Which of the following pairs of suspensions served as controls for the addition of sperm or the ionophore in Experiments 1 and 2, respectively?

questions.question: 25. Procaine is an anesthetic that prevents the release of Ca2+ from the cortical granules. Based on the information provided, the effect of the presence of procaine in the egg would be most similar to the effect of the presence of which of the following?

Two experiments were done to study the hypothesis that the sperm causes the egg to release Ca2+ into the cytoplasm, which then triggers the cortical reaction.

Experiment 1
Three suspensions of unfertilized sea urchin eggs in seawater containing no Ca2+ were prepared. Aequorin, a substance that luminesces (shines) in the presence of Ca2+, was injected into the eggs' cytoplasm. Sea urchin sperm or an ionophore (a substance that can enter an egg and transport Ca2+ across membranes) was then added to 2 of the suspensions. Eggs were examined for luminescence in the cytoplasm and for the presence of a fertilization membrane (see Table 1).

Experiment 2
Experiment 1 was repeated except that both aequorin and a substance called EDTA (which binds with Ca2+, keeping it from reacting with other substances) were injected (see Table 1).
questions.question: 26. Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2, which of the following is a plausible description of the role of the ionophore? The ionophore:

choices.A: causes Ca2+ to move from cortical granules into the cytoplasm of the egg.
choices.B: attracts the sperm to the vitelline layer of the egg.
choices.C: prevents a reaction from occurring between Ca2+ and aequorin in the cytoplasm of the egg.
choices.D: fuses the plasma membranes of the sperm and egg.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
When a sperm fertilizes a sea urchin egg, the egg's cortical granules (spherical structure, each bound by a membrane) fuse with the egg's plasma membrane. The contents of the granules, which include Ca2+ (unbound calcium ions), are released outward into the area between the plasma membrane and the vitelline layer (the egg's outer layer) in a process called the cortical reaction. The vitelline layer then expands to form the fertilization membrane. The fertilization membrane prevents other sperm from fusing with the egg (see figure 1).


Two experiments were done to study the hypothesis that the sperm causes the egg to release Ca2+ into the cytoplasm, which then triggers the cortical reaction.

Experiment 1
Three suspensions of unfertilized sea urchin eggs in seawater containing no Ca2+ were prepared. Aequorin, a substance that luminesces (shines) in the presence of Ca2+, was injected into the eggs' cytoplasm. Sea urchin sperm or an ionophore (a substance that can enter an egg and transport Ca2+ across membranes) was then added to 2 of the suspensions. Eggs were examined for luminescence in the cytoplasm and for the presence of a fertilization membrane (see Table 1).

Experiment 2
Experiment 1 was repeated except that both aequorin and a substance called EDTA (which binds with Ca2+, keeping it from reacting with other substances) were injected (see Table 1).
questions.question: 27. If, in Suspension 2, the eggs had NOT been injected with aequorin, which of the following results would most have likely have occurred?

choices.A: Luminescence would have occurred in the cytoplasm, and the fertilization membrane would have formed.
choices.B: Luminescence would have occurred in the cytoplasm, but the fertilization membrane would not have formed.
choices.C: Luminescence would not have occurred in the cytoplasm, but the fertilization membrane would have formed.
choices.D: Luminescence would not have occurred in the cytoplasm, and the fertilization membrane would not have formed.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
In a colorimeter, light of a specific wavelength is directed through a sample of solution onto a detector. If some of the components in the solution absorb some of the light, that light will not reach the detector. The solution's absorbance is related to the amount of light absorbed, and therefore, to the concentration of these components.

Dissolved iron (Fe) does not absorb visible light. However, when a certain indicator solution is added to an Fe solution, the Fe will react with the indicator solution to form Fe(SCN)6-3 ions, which absorb blue light.

Experiments were done to study the effects of boiling and canning on the Fe content of beans.


Experiment 1

Several 80 mL solutions with known concentrations (in mg/L) of Fe in H2O were each mixed with 20 mL of the indicator solution. The absorbance of blue light by each solution was then measured in a colorimeter (see Figure 1).


Experiment 2

Raw black beans were ground and 5 g were heated until only ash remained. The ash was placed in 20 mL of indicator solution. The mixture was filtered and the solution was then diluted to 100 mL withH2O. The absorbance was measured and the Fe concentration of the solution was determined using Figure 1. The Fe content of the beans (in mg/100 g) was then calculated. The procedure was repeated for boiled black beans and canned black beans, and then for other types of beans (see Table 1).


Table adapted from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, USDA Nutrient Database for Standard Reference, Release 13, 1999
questions.question: 28. Suppose that fava beans were evaluated as in Experiment 2. Based on the trends shown in Table 1, which of the following sets of results is most plausible for the Fe content (in mg/100 g) of raw, boiled, and canned fava beans?

Table adapted from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, USDA Nutrient Database for Standard Reference, Release 13, 1999
questions.question: 29. If, in Experiment 1, an additional solution had been prepared and its absorbance had been measured as 2.4, the concentration of Fe in the solution would most likely have been:

questions.question: 30. In Experiments 1 and 2, why was the indicator solution added to each of the Fe solutions？

choices.A: To determine the pH of the Fe solutions
choices.B: To determine the pH of the Fe(SCN)6-3  solutions
choices.C: To convert the Fe in the solutions into a substance that absorbs blue light
choices.D: To convert the Fe(SCN)6-3 in the solutions into a substance that absorbs blue light

questions.question: 32. Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2, the absorbance measured for the solution that was made using raw navy beans was closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 33. In order to plot and use Figure 1, the experimenter most likely made which of the following assumptions about each of the solutions measured in Experiments 1 and 2?

choices.A: All of the dissolved Fe in the solution reacted to form Fe(SCN)6-3.
choices.B: All of the Fe(SCN)6-3 in the solution reacted to form Fe ions.
choices.C: The solutions absorbed all of the blue light in the colorimeter.
choices.D: The solutions only contained Fe from bean samples.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
Introduction
 A fluid's viscosity is a measure of its resistance against flowing. In general, a fluid's viscosity decreases as its temperature increases. A fluid is Newtonian if its viscosity depends only on temperature. A fluid is non-Newtonian if its viscosity depends on both temperature and stress (increased pressure is an example of stress).

Some fluids are made by mixing particles with a liquid. Three models of such fluids are discussed below.


Sand-Water Model
 Many fluids behave like a mixture of sand and water. When this mixture flows, sand grains rub together. The friction between grains is a source of viscosity. If the grains are coated with water, the water lubricates the grains and reduces friction. Lubrication is most likely if the pores (the spaces between grains) are filled with water.

The average pore volume is lowest when the mixture has settled. If the settled mixture is squeezed, the average pore volume must increase so that the sand grains can move over each other. If the mixture is squeezed rapidly, water does not have time to fill the expanding pores, and the viscosity increases rapidly. If the mixture is squeezed more slowly, the viscosity increases more slowly.


Elongated Particle Model
 Many fluids contain particles that are elongated (long and narrow). In the absence of stress, these particles are oriented in no particular direction. Under stress, however the particles in some of these fluids become oriented perpendicular to the direction of their flow, increasing the fluids' viscosity; the particles in other fluids become oriented parallel to the direction of flow, decreasing the fluids' viscosity.


Charged Particle Model
 When a fluid is squeezed, its particles rub together and acquire positive or negative charges. Particles that are oppositely charged resist being pulled apart. This resistance increases the viscosity of the fluid. When the fluid is rapidly squeezed, the rate of charged particle production is higher than when the fluid is slowly squeezed.
questions.question: 34. According to the introduction to the passage, as a fluid gets hotter, its resistance to flow most likely will change in which, if any, of the following ways?

choices.A: Its resistance to flow will increase.
choices.B: Its resistance to flow will decrease.
choices.C: Its resistance to flow is as likely to increase as it is to decrease.
choices.D: Its resistance to flow will be unaffected by an increase in temperature.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
Introduction
 A fluid's viscosity is a measure of its resistance against flowing. In general, a fluid's viscosity decreases as its temperature increases. A fluid is Newtonian if its viscosity depends only on temperature. A fluid is non-Newtonian if its viscosity depends on both temperature and stress (increased pressure is an example of stress).

Some fluids are made by mixing particles with a liquid. Three models of such fluids are discussed below.


Sand-Water Model
 Many fluids behave like a mixture of sand and water. When this mixture flows, sand grains rub together. The friction between grains is a source of viscosity. If the grains are coated with water, the water lubricates the grains and reduces friction. Lubrication is most likely if the pores (the spaces between grains) are filled with water.

The average pore volume is lowest when the mixture has settled. If the settled mixture is squeezed, the average pore volume must increase so that the sand grains can move over each other. If the mixture is squeezed rapidly, water does not have time to fill the expanding pores, and the viscosity increases rapidly. If the mixture is squeezed more slowly, the viscosity increases more slowly.


Elongated Particle Model
 Many fluids contain particles that are elongated (long and narrow). In the absence of stress, these particles are oriented in no particular direction. Under stress, however the particles in some of these fluids become oriented perpendicular to the direction of their flow, increasing the fluids' viscosity; the particles in other fluids become oriented parallel to the direction of flow, decreasing the fluids' viscosity.


Charged Particle Model
 When a fluid is squeezed, its particles rub together and acquire positive or negative charges. Particles that are oppositely charged resist being pulled apart. This resistance increases the viscosity of the fluid. When the fluid is rapidly squeezed, the rate of charged particle production is higher than when the fluid is slowly squeezed.
questions.question: 35. A squeezable bottle contains a mixture of sand and water with the lowest average pore volume, as shown in Figure A below. When the mixture is squeezed, the sand level climbs higher in the bottle, as shown in Figure B below. Based on the Sand-Water Model, the reason the sand level increases is most likely that there is an increase in the average:

choices.D: volume of water in the bottle.

questions.article:

questions.question: 36. A certain fluid is harder to squeeze the more rapidly it is squeezed. Based on the Sand-Water Model, which of the following statements best explains this result?

choices.A: Many of the particles do not get lubricated by the liquid.
choices.B: Many of the particles dissolve in the liquid.
choices.C: The rate of charge production increases rapidly when the mixture is squeezed rapidly.
choices.D: The particles are wider than they are long.

questions.article:

questions.question: 37. Suppose that when a fluid is kept below a certain critical temperature, T, the fluid's viscosity changes with both temperature and stress. When the fluid is kept above T, its viscosity changes with temperature but not with stress. Based on the introduction to the passage, this fluid is best described by which of the following statements?

choices.A: The fluid is non-Newtonian below T and Newtonian above T.
choices.B: The fluid is Newtonian below T and non-Newtonian above T.
choices.C: The fluid is Newtonian both below and above T.
choices.D: The fluid is non-Newtonian both below and above T.

questions.question: 38. Non-Newtonian behavior is consistent with which of the following models?

choices.C: The Sand-Water and Elongated Particle Models only
choices.D: The Sand-Water, Charged Particle, and Elongated Particle Models

questions.question: 39. According to the passage, which of the following procedures will be most likely to increase a fluid's viscosity?

choices.C: Rapidly decreasing the pressure on the fluid
choices.D: Slowly decreasing the pressure on the fluid

questions.question: 40. According to the Sand-Water Model, the friction among particles in a fluid will most gradually increase as pressure on the mixture is:
